title: Global vegetation dynamics
description:
Annual bias and trend-corrected metrics on intra-annual 
vegetation dynamics expressed through the NDVI
contents:
Details


This dataset provides intra-annual metrics based on a daily time-series
of Normalized Difference Vegetation Indices (NDVI). This time-series was
corrected to account for the continued deterioration of the AVHRR
sensors following the methodology proposed by Hansen et al. (2016).


Subdatasets

Intra-annual NDVI amplitude
content

NDVI values between the 10th and 30th percentiles

NDVI values between the 30th and 50th percentiles
content
description
value_range
-1…1
ndviP50to70 | Mean of
NDVI values between the 50th and 70th percentiles
content
description
value_range
-1…1
ndviP70to90 | Mean of
NDVI values between the 70th and 90th percentiles
content
description

-1…1

# data call for specific subdataset

title: Global climate classification
description: High-resolution climate classification following the Koppen-Geiger class cheme.
contents:
Details


The present-day map is derived from an ensemble of four high-resolution,
topographically-corrected climatic maps. The future map is derived from
an ensemble of 32 climate model projections (scenario RCP8.5), by
superimposing the projected climate change anomaly on the baseline
high-resolution climatic maps. For both time periods we calculate
confidence levels from the ensemble spread, providing valuable
indications of the reliability of the classifications. The new maps
exhibit a higher classification accuracy and substantially more detail
than previous maps, particularly in regions with sharp spatial or
elevation gradients.

title: Bias-corrected CCI land cover
description:
Trend-corrected CCI land cover dataset with annual and global 
data on per-pixel percentages of 27 classes.
contents:
Details


This dataset corrects issues observed in land cover dataset of ESA’s
Climate Change Initiative (CCI). The original data maps implausible
changes caused by methodological artificats, which often manifest as
false, country-wide land cover transitions. We corrected for these
anomalies with the support ofannual Vegetation Continuous Fields (VCF)
data mapped at a 300-m resolution, which we used to identify and correct
errogenous pixels. The output is a bias-corrected land cover dataset
with novel class combinations and per-pixel percentages for dominant
vegetated classes.

title: CCI land cover
description:
Global, yearly land cover derived in the context of the 
Climate Change Initiative (CCI), from 1992 to the present
contents:
Details


This data provides information on the spatial and temporal evolution of
22 land cover classes, which have been defined using the United Nations
Food and Agriculture Organization’s (UN FAO) Land Cover Classification
System (LCCS). To produce this dataset, the entire Medium Resolution
Imaging Spectrometer (MERIS) Full and Reduced Resolution archive from
2003 to 2012 was first classified into a unique 10-year baseline LC map.
This is thenback- and up-dated using change detected from (i) Advanced
Very-High-Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) time series from 1992 to 1999,
(ii) SPOT-Vegetation (SPOT-VGT) time series from 1998 to 2012 and (iii)
PROBA-Vegetation (PROBA-V) and Sentinel-3 OLCI (S3 OLCI) time series
from 2013.

title: CCI land cover history
description:
Historical maximum extent of generic land cover types derived from the 
CCI land cover dataset
contents:
Details


This dataset provides historical representations of the spatial
distribution of generic land cover classes. To derive these data, we
thematicaly aggregated the CCI land cover into generic class groups
(e.g. agriculture, desertic) on a yearly
basis. Then, for each derived layer, we derived a mask with its maximum
historical extent. Finally, we resampled the output to a 1-km
resolution, depicting per-pixel percentages of the given class group.


Subdatasets

desertic | Maximum
historical extent of bare land and rocky areas (%)

description

0…100

title: Annual permafrost extents
description: Time-series of the extent of permafrost in the northern hemisphere
contents:
Details


Permafrost underlies approximately one quarter of the terrestrial
Northern Hemisphere. Under the threat of climate change, the warming
soils lead permafrost to decrease in extent, affecting the microbial
breakdown of organic carbon and the consequent release of greenhouse
gases. This dataset allows us to observed the long-term variability of
permafrost. Developed in the context of the Climate Change Initiative
(CCI), this dataset covers the period of 1997 to 2018 at a 1-km
resolution. We resampled this dataset to a 300-m resolution. When the
permafrost cover was below 100%, the respective percent cover was
divided equaly among the 300-m pixels underlying a 1-km pixel.
Additionally, the period of 1992 to 1996 was covered by replicating the
1997 state.


Subdatasets

percentCover |
Per-pixel extent of permafrost (%)
content
description
value_range
0…100

masDMT query



# data call without specifying subdataset and resolution

# data call for specific subdataset

# data call to subdataset with a specific resolution
list_data("CCI_permafrost/percentCover/300m")

contents:

snow cover estimated in the scope of Climate Change Initiative (CCI).
Here, we aggregated the daily layers on a monthly basis, reporting on
maximum, annual, per-pixel percentages, and on the frequency of months
with observed snow cover.

title: Global high-resolution climate
description: Global monthly time-series of precipitation and temperature.
contents:
Details


CHELSA provides monthly data on precipitation and temperature, derived
by downscaling global atmospheric models. The temperature data is based
on statistical downscaling of atmospheric temperatures, while the
precipitation data incorporates orographic predictors such as wind
fields, valley exposition, and boundary layer height, with a subsequent
bias correction.

title: Annual nighttime lights
description:
Global time-series of Nighttime light intensities mapped by 
the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP)
contents:
Details


This dataset provides yearly, global maps on the spatial and temporal
variability of night lights (NTL). This dataset derives a temporally
consistent NTL dataset by harmonizing DMSP data, availble up to 2013,
with simulated DMSP-like NTL observations from the VIIRS data. With this
method, we obtain a longer DMSP time-series, up to 2018.


Subdatasets

title: Fused vegetation continuous fields
description:
Annual and global Vegetation Continuous Fields (VCF) 
that fuses data from Copernicus, MODIS, and AVHRR
contents:
Details


This dataset extends on the AVHRR-based VCF dataset developed by Hansen
et al. (2016) by integrating MODIS and Copernicus data. We used a Random
Forest model to translate these data into AVHRR-like layers, assuring
their continuity past 2016 in support of multi-decadal monitoring
applications.

title: Global impervious surfaces
description: Annual time-series of impervious surfaces
contents:

This dataset was derived thorugh the classification of dense satellite
time series obtained with multiple Landsat sensors. It provides data on
the first year an impervious pixel was observed starting from 1985. The
original dataset, with a spatial resolution of 30-m, was then split into
yearly layers and aggreated into 300-m layers with yearly per-pixel
percentages.

Produced by the Joint Research Centre (JRC), this dataset offers a
global, multi-temporal perspetice on the spatial distribution of human

integrates gridded data on urban settlements with census data on human
populations to generate a combine product, downscaling census data to
the pixel level.

title: Annual Area of Habitat (AoH)
description:
Global and species-specific layers on the area 
of habitat mapped on a species-by-species basis.
contents:
Details


This dataset maps the AoH for over 34,000 species, based on the habitat
dependencies of each species as reported by the IUCN Red List. It is
derived by intersecting the GlobES dataset with the species-specific
range maps and accounts for the accessibilty to habitat patches outside
the expert-drawn ranges motivated by knowledge of the dispersal ability
of each species.

title: Global mountain classification
description: Global Mountain Maps
contents:
Details


This dataset offers different classifications of mountains following
different definitions. The K1 resource used a 1 km DEM which was
processed using a combination of elevation, slope and relative relief.
Relative relief, or ruggedness, is the difference between maximum and
minimum elevation in a moving neighborhood analysis window (NAW) and is
computed for every raster cell. The K1 layer defined six classes of
mountains, where the upper three classes were defined by elevation
ranges. The lower three classes were defined either by a combination of
elevation and slope, or elevation and relative relief. The circular NAW
for computing the relative relief used a 5 pixel (~7 km) radius for an
approximate NAW size of 150 km2. The K2 resource was developed using
ruggedness as the determining factor, where any relative relief greater
than 200m in the NAW was considered mountainous. The original K2
resource used a 1 km DEM and an approximately 9km2 NAW to determine
relative relief and then generalized the relative relief surface to an
approximately 4.5 km grid (at the equator). The K3 resource was
developed using a finer spatial resolution (250 m) DEM and feature-based
extraction algorithms with variable NAW sizes used to extract a set of
global Hammond landforms with 16 landform types, of which four were
mountain classes. E. H. Hammond was a pioneer of landform mapping and
described three parameters for distinguishing different types of plains,
hills, mountains, and tablelands. The three classification parameters
are slope, relative relief, and profile, where the profile parameter
assesses the amount of relatively flat terrain in upland locations to
delineate tablelands. The 250 m global Hammond landforms product was
based on an automated extraction of classes in a GIS environment, and
the K3 mountains product was an export of the four mountain classes into
a global mountains datalayer.

title: Global hydrological basins
description: Deliniated of watershed at different hierarchical levels
contents:
Details


These data were obtaiend from the HydroBASINS dataset, which offers
spatial data on watershed boundaries at multiple hierarchical levels.
The watershed deliniation follows the topological concept of the
Pfafstetter coding system (levels 1-12). Here, we use only a subset of
the afformentioned dataset, comprising Pfafstetter levels 2, 3, and 12.

title: Land surface phenology
description: Typical phenology of deciduous forests derived with PROBA-V data time-series
contents:
Details


This dataset provides information on the average per-pixel phenology of
deciduous forests. It maps the Start of Season (SoS), Mid of Season
(MoS) and End of Season (EoS), which is through a threshold method
applied over a time-series of intra and inter-annual Normalized
Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). The NDVI time-series was measured
with the PROBA-V between 1999 and 2017.

title: Annual Landsat data quality
description: Landsat acquisition quality mapped on a yearly basis
contents:
Details


This dataset provides per-pixel information on the frequency and quality
of Landsat acquisitions between 1982 and 2020. For each year, we counted
the number of acquisitions and evaluated the intra-annual acqusition
quality. The closer the quality metric is in value to the acquisition
frequency, the better the quality of the satellite images. In addition,
this dataset provides a quality index, which is the quotient between the
image quality metric and the acquisition frequency. The closest the
output is to 1, the highest the quality of the imagery in the given
year.


Subdatasets

imageFrequency | Number
of satellite acquisitions per pixel
content
description
monthFrequency | Number
of observed months
content
description
quality | Sum of
quality weights per pixel
content
description
value_range
0…n
distributionQuality |
Normalized metric on the balance of image quality across the year
content
description
value_range
0…1
nrTiles | Number of
tiles contribution with acquisitions
content
description
value_range
0…n

title: Global elevation
description: Multi-Error-Removed Improved-Terrain (MERIT) Digital Elevation Model (DEM)
contents:
Details


MERIT DEM is a high accuracy global DEM with a resolution of 90 m. It
combines multiple existing DEM datasets (NASA SRTM3 DEM, JAXA AW3D DEM,
Viewfinder Panoramas DEM), making use of their combined strenghts to
address their individual weaknesses. The present version of this dataset
was aggregated to 300 m. Furthermore, the dataset was combined with
GEBCO bathymetry data, which was added to oceanic data gaps in the MERIT
DEM.


Subdatasets

per-pixel elevation

title: Global rivers
description:
Hydrological variables derived with the Multi-Error-Removed 
Improved-Terrain (MERIT) Digital Elevation Model (DEM)
contents:
Details


This dataset used flow direction data (based on the MERIT DEM dataset)
modeled in combination withwater body datasets (G1WBM, GSWO, and
OpenStreetMap) to extract river networks.

title: Global pixel areas
description: Per-pixel areas for global applications
contents:
Details


This dataset provides per-pixel estimtes of areas within a WGS84,
lat/lon grid. This layer was derived with the Harvesine method, which
estimates the distance in meters of a distance between two geographical
points. This method was used to estimate the distance between the edges
of a pixel, across both latitude and longitude. These distances were
then used to estimate the are of the pixel.


Subdatasets

area in hectares

title: Soil climatologies
description: Soil temperature bioclimatic variables
contents:
Details


These dataset consists of soil temperature layers calculated by adding
monthly soil temperature offsets to monthly air-temperature maps from
the CHELSA dataset. These soil temperature layers were then used to
calculate annual means, temperature ranges, standard deviation, warmest
and coldest months and quarters. Wettest and driest quarters were
identified for each pixel based on CHELSA monthly values.

title: Soil characteristics
description: Gridded soil database (soilGrids)
contents:
Details


This dataset provides global maps of soil properties derived with
state-of-the-art machine learning methods. SoilGrids prediction models
are fitted using over 230,000 soil profile observations from the WoSIS
database and a series of environmental covariates. Covariates were
selected from a pool of over 400 environmental layers (e.g. climate,
land cover), and originated from different data products derived with
Earth observation data. The outputs of SoilGrids are global soil
property maps at six standard depth intervals (according to the
GlobalSoilMap IUSS working group and its specifications). Prediction
uncertainty is quantified by the lower and upper limits of a 90%
prediction interval.

title: Global Sea surface temperature
description: Annual maximum Sea Surface Temperature (SST)
contents:
Details


This dataset maps the global, yearly maximum SST derived from daily mean
estimates. The daily estimates are the result of the fusion of data from
multiple satellite sensors. It combines data from the Advanced Very High
Resolution Radiometers (AVHRRs), the series of Along Track Scanning
Radiometers (ATSRs), and the Sea and Land Surface Temperature Radiometer
(SLSTR).

title: Annual water balance
description: Global climate and water balance time series.
contents:
Details


This dataset provides monthly climate and climatic water balance
variables. TerraClimate uses climatically aided interpolation, combining
high-spatial resolution climatological normals from the WorldClim
dataset, with coarser resolution time varying (i.e., monthly) data from
other sources to produce a monthly dataset of precipitation,
temperature, wind speed, vapor pressure, and solar radiation.
TerraClimate additionally produces monthly surface water balance
datasets using a water balance model that incorporates reference
evapotranspiration, precipitation, temperature, and interpolated plant
extractable soil water capacity.


Subdatasets

totalPrecipitation |
Total precipitation (mm)
content
description
value_range
0…n

Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI)
content
description
value_range
0…n

Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI)
content

title: Global map of tidal flats
description: Global distribution of tidal flats
contents:
Details


This datasets maps tidal flats globally, derived with 707,528 Landsat
acquisitions. These acquisitions were classified using Machine learning
thorugh Google Earth Engine. The original data is provided at a 30-m
resolution and on 5-year epochs. Here, we filled temporal gaps with the
nearest year, and aggregated the original masks to into 300-m resolution
layers, expressing per-pixel percentages of tidal flats.


Subdatasets

percent cover of tidal flats

title: Tropical moist forest cover
description: Annual tropical moist forest cover densities
contents:
Details


The Joint Research Centre of the European Commission developed a dataset
on forest cover change in tropical moist forests (TMF) using 39 years of
Landsat time series (30 m). We aggregated these data to a 300 m
resolution, deriving yearly layers on sub-pixel proportions of forests.
Futhermore, using the long-term change information of the original
dataset, we reconstructed yearly extents of mangrove forest. Note that
mangroves are a subset of the forest cover density layers, and therefore
should not be used complementary.


Subdatasets

cover density (%)

value_range
